Another advantage of writing small modules that follow single responsibility principle: links in external docs to the file are sufficient.
Pointers to line numbers are not needed (and will wrong with the next change to the file anyway).
There is still no great way to document a cross section of an architecture spanning multiples repos and concerns.
I'm using a typical request livecycle, from UI layer to storage and back, mixing prose, code snippets and links to repos, implementation.
So you have one longe wiki page, that takes you through all the hoops.
Swimlane diagrams are just no good for explanatory text.
@NicoleRauch Yes, that's a good method, but how does the artefact looks like, that explains HTTP requests, status codes, connections to databases, etc.
@NicoleRauch And the the implementation details of key components (e.g. transformation of domain object to representation in persistence or API response)

@NicoleRauch This is what I'm writing right now: https://t.co/wGsmOiSZgc
It starts with an overview of the components and then does the deep dive.

I realized that there is a "full-stack developer trap": your work is evaluated based on your best skill, which unfulfillable expectations.
I would consider myself to be a full-stack developer, but my strength is building backend systems for complex processes.
I started my careers as a frontend developer and have been building frontends throughout my various types of employment.
I'd say I know frontend technologies VERY well. And that gets me very far.
Because I know how everything works together it's easy for me to use frontend frameworks to build production quality frontend components.
But going beyond that, we are looking at UX and in the end design. Going from Bootstrap to the next level, is something I can't do.
And this is where it gets tricky: If I'm confrontend with a backend task, I can always go further and provide excellent solutions.
For a non-technical founder, though, they do not distinguish between backend and frontend work.
And they will implicitly expect my frontend work results to be equally sophisticated as my backend work.
And I maneuver myself into this trap by using frameworks like Bootstrap. They enable me to have great looking components, without designing.
It seems we got lucky. We checked in online yesterday. Flight delayed and there where huge lines at the check-in counters. #bcnüá™üá∏ #lufthansa
And after that it gets hard, and there needs to be designers, ux/ui experts. And I know that, but at this point it's actually too late.

It's now really hard to explain that to your team.
Here is what you can do: make your skill distribution explicit when working in that role.
As a full-stack developer your are sought after in early stage startups, small teams because you can deliver everything they need as one.
Because they are so fundamentally different, and keeping up with technical developments on both ends is nearly impossible.
Make clear for which of the many roles you hold, you expect to be replaced and how quickly and what you want to keep doing forever.
I know this sounds contradictive to the term full-stack developer, but I've never met one that truly excels in and loves both disciplines.
This will help your team to commit to finding a replacement for you from the start of a project.
And having you makes it easy to add more and more projects / features. Because you can do it. But be aware of your limitations.
So a better description would be "full-stack literate".
@lufthansa Yes, we are in LH1125 now. So everything üëå!

@wa7son Importing of submodules is way more comfortable (only one line for multiple).
@dasilvacontin @wa7son https://t.co/hNs7ubB6pC
Some scary stuff: https://t.co/EQC2RH3UfF
@dasilvacontin @malditogeek @wa7son @CodeByHeart And getting rid of require() is also about enabling static code analysis.
@jannisborgers I'd put a timer on the door, though. ;-)
@zoranzaric Yeah, the whole day, pretty awesome! I also love the comments on HN.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart With require() it's possible to load modules from composite pathes: require('./modules/' + name + '-plugin').
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart This makes it only possible to know which module is actually being loaded during runtime.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart Therefore require() must be synchronous, which has performance implications.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart And you can't statically analyze your codebase to know which modules you are really using.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart Because ES modules are resolved during compile time, they can be loaded asynch and you can't use composite pathes.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart During coding: not so much really.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart Well, that might be true now, but in a few months once ES modules have been approved, we will see an important use case for that:
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart reducing boot-up time of node processes. Which is especially important for lambdas / very small instances.
@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart Sure, currently it's only a question whether you like the syntax or not. The benefits are neglectable currently.
@dasilvacontin @wa7son @malditogeek @CodeByHeart No because you will be able to optimize the startup process:

@dasilvacontin @wa7son @malditogeek @CodeByHeart With require():
Execute code
Load modules
Execute code
Load modules
Done

With ES modules:
Load ALL modules
Execute code
Done

@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart Yes, but I still have libraries with 10-20 classes.
Also within a project, for me importing multiple exports from one module is not uncommon

@wa7son @dasilvacontin @malditogeek @CodeByHeart Right now, it's just syntax. Everything else is theory.
So, pick what you prefer, but require() is probably going away.
